project.teaser: UP2030 aims to guide cities through the socio-technical transitions required to meet their climate neutrality ambitions. It will do so by enabling a quantum leap from a ´business as usual´, project-by-project decarbonisation approach to a vision-driven, strategy-based...
project.objective: UP2030 aims to guide cities through the socio-technical transitions required to meet their climate neutrality ambitions. It will do so by enabling a quantum leap from a ´business as usual´, project-by-project decarbonisation approach to a vision-driven, strategy-based approach that is anchored on sound projects and renewed policy development. The approach uses urban planning and design as a vehicle to create better connected, more compact, net-zero neighbourhoods in the city pilots – i.e. neighbourhoods that promote liveability and, through designing with intent, promote mitigation action. Unlike fragmented innovation processes that focus on the deployment of a specific solution to achieve incremental progress, UP2030 proposes that cities should themselves be at the centre of the innovation approach to drive transformative change. The project develops the 5UP methodological framework that supports cities in (i) UP-dating those policies, codes, regulations that need to be left behind to make room for the new vision (ii) UP-skilling, through building the capacities of the entire city stakeholder ecosystem that shall deliver actions (iii) UP-grading, through the development of solution prototypes (digital and physical) at selected neighbourhoods, (iv) UP-scaling to achieve city-wide impact by shaping the enabling governance arrangements and matching project portfolios to financial resources, and (v) UP-taking, by engaging with the Mission and sharing best practices across European cities. Inclusive participation is key throughout the project’s full cycle of activities so that real needs of communities are reflected in the city-specific visions, and co-designed interventions maximise delivery of co-benefits. As such, UP2030 will (a) have a measured positive impact on spatial justice in the pilots, and (b) give the opportunity to citizens to participate in the transition by becoming agents of change themselves through their sustainable behavioural shifts.
project.title: Urban Planning and design ready for 2030
project.keywords: urban design, climate, neutrality, Mission, decarbonisation, sustainability, justice, climate resilience, equity

article.title: EU Missions to address climate change in cities and regions
article.teaser: In the face of unprecedented challenges posed by climate change, the European Union has embarked on an ambitious journey towards a sustainable and resilient future. The EU Missions on Adaptation to Climate Change and on Climate-Neutral and Smart Cities under Horizon Europe, the EU’s key funding programme for research and innovation, represent significant pillars in this transformative endeavour. This brochure showcases 14 European-funded Mission projects that show the collaborative spirit, innovation and commitment required to address the pressing issues of climate change.

webItem.title: Living with climate change
webItem.alternativeText: The EU Mission on Adaptation to Climate Change is supporting at least 150 European regions in becoming climate-resilient by 2030. The infographic illustrates several examples. In Zagreb, Croatia, 1500 new trees alleviate extreme heat on city streets. In the Canary Islands, better aquifer measurements help islanders manage water resources. In the Berlin-Brandenburg region, authorities will balance increased water demand with an expected 40 % drop in surface water. In the Netherlands, floating houses are one way flood risk is being integrated into urban planning. A pilot in Croatia and Slovakia uses mesh networks and autonomous vehicles to combat wildfires.

webItem.title: Metro metrics
webItem.alternativeText: Cities are home to 75% of EU citizens and generate 70% of CO2 emissions. Transitioning to smart and carbon-neutral cities will mean deploying a range of technologies, strategies and governance tools. The infographic presents the share of urban greenhouse gas emissions by sector: Stationary energy 55%, Transport 26.3%, Waste and wastewater treatment 3.1%, Industrial processes and products use 12.5%, Agriculture, forestry and other land use 2.1%, Other 1%. Source: Self reported data from 105 Mission Cities. Data was not externally verified and not all cities presented comprehensive data on emissions.

result.title: Report on vision co-design methodology report and its application for pilot shared visions
result.description: Developing and applying the vision co-design methodology for all pilots.Report on vision co-design methodology explaining how it was deployed and its application for UP2030 pilot cities, including KPIs, GHG emission metrics, integrating carbon neutrality, resilience and justice, indicators assessing environmental, socio-economic & demographic (SED), and behavioural change indicators.

result.title: Bundle of digital twin tools for net zero decision-making 1
result.description: First version of Digital Energy Twin resources responding to the implementation roadmaps of all pilot cities.Bundle of digital twin tools adapting existing Digital Twins of urban environments, describing the pilot environments at the necessary built and natural environment spatial and temporal resolution, as well as incorporating user behaviour characteristics, including BIM and CIM energy integration models for net zero decision-making. First version.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
